Comment:
Interesting rant, but let‚Äôs be honest, you left out the best part of the VC business model

For that ‚Çπ200 Cr fund, assuming a 2‚Äì20 structure and 10-year cycle, the fund will charge ~‚Çπ40 Cr in fees to LPs
By year 4, you are already raising a bigger ‚Çπ300 Cr+ fund, so fee income doubles quickly. Not a bad business model

With this fee, the promise to LPs is: ‚Äúwe‚Äôll find the best opportunities, invest in them, & deliver outsized returns.‚Äù In practice, these returns are as mythical for most funds as unicorns

Now, if you think of yourself as a business, you actually have two stakeholders: LPs & startups. Since your revenue comes from startups (exits, upside), they are essentially your customers. Dismissing early founders because of ‚Äúlack of brand‚Äù or"story" (seriously!) feels more like lazy customer service than risk-taking.

When a fund insists on only backing pedigreed founders, it usually signals poor groundwork & a lack of conviction in its own thesis. It‚Äôs the equivalent of saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll only buy stocks that some big-shot investor is buying, because I don‚Äôt trust my own judgment.‚Äù 

That‚Äôs also how we end up with bloated valuations & overfunded darlings where governance takes a backseat, something the ecosystem has already seen.
